# FDA Approves Narsoplimab for Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant–Associated Thrombotic Microangiopathy

Author(s) [_Kristi Rosa_](https://www.onclive.com/authors/kristi-rosa)

Listen

0:00 / NaN:NaN

The FDA has approved narsoplimab for the treatment of hematopoietic stem cell transplant-associated thrombotic microangiopathy.

FDA

![](https://cdn.sanity.io/images/0vv8moc6/onclive/5932c60f25c2473585b3b9a3d2042fbba905f2a3-582x800.jpg?fit=crop&auto=format)

The FDA has approved narsoplimab-wuug (Yartemlea) injection for the treatment of adults and children aged 2 years and older with hematopoietic stem cell transplant–associated thrombotic microangiopathy (TA-TMA).1

The efficacy of the lectin pathway inhibitor was evaluated in 28 patients enrolled in the single-arm, open-label TA-TMA Study. Data from an additional 19 evaluable patients enrolled in an expanded access program (EAP) also supported the regulatory decision.

Findings from the TA-TMA Study indicated that [**narsoplimab**](https://www.onclive.com/view/narsoplimab-elicits-high-response-rate-improves-organ-function-in-hsct-tma) elicited a TMA complete response (CR) rate of 61% (95% CI, 40.6%-78.5%) in evaluable adult patients (n = 28); this rate was 68% in the evaluable EAP patients. When broken down further, the TMA response rate was 67% (95% CI, 22.3%-95.7%) in pediatric patients (n = 6) and 69% (95% CI, 38.6%-90.9%) in adult patients (n = 13) in the EAP.2
